top_categories.workout_context: At 100 miles, Rock Cobbler punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Rock Cobbler’s central valley gravel, rocky sections demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Rock Cobbler isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Rock Cobbler rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Rock Cobbler when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Rock Cobbler. Make this intensity feel like home.
Every session at Rock Cobbler intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Rock Cobbler’s central valley gravel and dirt—rocks, rollers and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
At 100 miles, Rock Cobbler rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Rock Cobbler — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Rock Cobbler’s central valley gravel and dirt—rocks, rollers delivers on race day.
Rock Cobbler’s 5,000ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.

race_overlay.heat: February in Bakersfield, California can bring heat. Complete 3–4 heat exposure sessions in the final 2 weeks before Rock Cobbler. Increase sodium intake 48 hours before race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Rock Cobbler’s 100 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Rock Cobbler requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on central valley gravel and dirt—rocks, rollers to build confidence. Expect: central valley gravel, rocky sections, dirt roads.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 100 miles of central valley gravel and dirt—rocks, rollers in Bakersfield, California.
